rows.title: Praise yourself

transcript.eng:
Self-praise can be really helpful, especially when we have difficult days. 

Think of your week and finish the following phrase: “This week, I am proud of myself for …” It can be anything, not just things about being a parent!

Think of one thing you did well today. Now wrap your arms around yourself and give yourself a big HUG!

rows.transcript:
Self-praise can be really helpful, especially when we have difficult days. 

Think of your week and finish the following phrase: “This week, I am proud of myself for …” It can be anything, not just things about being a parent!

Think of one thing you did well today. Now wrap your arms around yourself and give yourself a big HUG!

text_1.eng: Being a great parent also means taking time to care for yourself every day. It starts with recognising how you feel.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: So good to hear you are feeling well today. You are incredible!

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: We all have days where we just don’t know. That is okay! You are here and that is what matters.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Being a parent can be hard. But you are here and that shows you want to keep improving things. That is a big accomplishment already!

section_1_text.eng:
This module includes content that may be sensitive. You can check it out by yourself first. This will prepare you well for sharing the content with your teen and others afterwards.

If you need support, see the “Support Contacts” section in your Library for help.

rows.section_1_text:
This module includes content that may be sensitive. You can check it out by yourself first. This will prepare you well for sharing the content with your teen and others afterwards.

If you need support, see the “Support Contacts” section in your Library for help.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Our topic today is staying safe.

To keep our teens safe, we need to understand their reality and the potential risky situations they can find themselves in.

We can help our teens know how to use their thoughts, voice, AND body in dangerous situations. It makes a big difference!

media_title.eng: Why is discussing safety with your teen important? Click play to find out

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings everyone.

Our topic is staying safe.

As parents it is important to ensure that our teens are safe at all times. Our safety and our children’s safety is important. We may need to have discussions with our children about their safety, and how they can keep themselves safe always.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Our topic today is staying safe.

To keep our teens safe, we need to understand their reality and the potential risky situations they can find themselves in.

We can help our teens know how to use their thoughts, voice, AND body in dangerous situations. It makes a big difference!
rows.media_title: Why is discussing safety with your teen important? Click play to find out
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings everyone.

Our topic is staying safe.

As parents it is important to ensure that our teens are safe at all times. Our safety and our children’s safety is important. We may need to have discussions with our children about their safety, and how they can keep themselves safe always.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Practising how to recognise warning signs and how to respond can help teens feel confident to protect themselves when it matters most.

media_title.eng: Hear how learning warning signs kept @data.characters.media_female_11.name's teen safe

media_transcript.eng:
Learning how to stay safe really helped us. The other day, my daughter got invited to a party by an older boy, and he said he would pay for her transport. Before, she would just go secretly, but now she came to me to talk about it.

We reminded each other that it is important to see the warning signs and stay safe, and she decided to say ‘no’. I am so proud of her. Even me, I now know that others should not pressure or convince me to do something. I can give the right example to my children.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Practising how to recognise warning signs and how to respond can help teens feel confident to protect themselves when it matters most.
rows.media_title: Hear how learning warning signs kept @data.characters.media_female_11.name's teen safe
rows.media_transcript:
Learning how to stay safe really helped us. The other day, my daughter got invited to a party by an older boy, and he said he would pay for her transport. Before, she would just go secretly, but now she came to me to talk about it.

We reminded each other that it is important to see the warning signs and stay safe, and she decided to say ‘no’. I am so proud of her. Even me, I now know that others should not pressure or convince me to do something. I can give the right example to my children.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
People can make us feel safe and happy—but sometimes they pressure us or make us uncomfortable. This can happen to both teens and adults.

Knowing the warning signs helps us stay safe.

Let’s look at some examples.

text_2.eng: Boyfriend pressures @data.characters.f1_daughter_16.name to go beyond kissing

character_1_text.eng: I don't think I am ready..

character_2_text.eng: Oh come on... We are ready for the next step. We see each other all the time and we never do anything more… You know I love you, right!

quiz_1_question.eng:
What warning signs do you see here?

The boyfriend:

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: Does not listen to @data.characters.f1_daughter_16.name or ask what she wants

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Yes, these are clear warning signs.

No one should push or convince you to do something you don’t want to do or feel unsure about. Even if you did it once, you can always change your mind—anytime, even during an intimate moment.

A partner who really loves and respects you will ask if you’re okay, listen to you, and stop if you say no.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng:
Yes, these are clear warning signs.

No one should push or convince you to do something you don’t want to do or feel unsure about. Even if you did it once, you can always change your mind—anytime, even during an intimate moment.

A partner who really loves and respects you will ask if you’re okay, listen to you, and stop if you say no.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: Makes @data.characters.f1_daughter_16.name feel bad about how she acts

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng:
Yes, these are clear warning signs.

No one should push or convince you to do something you don’t want to do or feel unsure about. Even if you did it once, you can always change your mind—anytime, even during an intimate moment.

A partner who really loves and respects you will ask if you’re okay, listen to you, and stop if you say no.

People can make us feel safe and happy—but sometimes they pressure us or make us uncomfortable. This can happen to both teens and adults.

Knowing the warning signs helps us stay safe.

Let’s look at some examples.

rows.character_1_text: I don't think I am ready..
rows.character_2_text: Oh come on... We are ready for the next step. We see each other all the time and we never do anything more… You know I love you, right!

character_2_text.eng: No, you are staying here. You always leave me alone to go see your friends. Don’t you love me? Or are you meeting your other boyfriend?!

quiz_1_question.eng:
What warning signs do you see here?

The boyfriend:

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Yes, all of these are warning signs! When we are in love, it can be hard to recognise something is wrong in our relationship.

If you have a friend in @data.characters.f1_daughter_16.name’s situation, try to help them see that jealous, possessive or controlling behaviour is not healthy or loving.

text_2.eng: @data.characters.f1_son_18.name’s friend shouts sexual comment at a girl

character_1_text.eng: Hey pretty, why are you walking so fast! Don’t you want to come show us what is under that skirt?

quiz_1_question.eng:
What warning signs do you see here?

The friend:

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Yes, all of these are warning signs!

Shouting sexual comments, whistling, or making kissing sounds at someone is sexual harassment and a type of abuse.

If @data.characters.f1_son_18.name stays quiet, his friend may keep doing it. He can help his friend understand that this behaviour is not okay and can make girls feel scared, angry, or sad.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: Makes the girl feel uncomfortable about how she looks and acts

character_1_text.eng: Hi beautiful, can I buy you a snack?

quiz_1_question.eng: What warning signs do you see here?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Yes, all of these are warning signs! It is common for young women to be pressured into sex when men offer food, gifts, or money.

Whenever you do not get the space to make your own decisions, that can be dangerous. Your friends, and others, should respect your choices.

rows.character_1_text: Hi beautiful, can I buy you a snack?

character_1_text.eng: Look, I still have this sexy picture that @data.characters.friend_female_2.name sent me! I will post it online, that should teach her not to break up with me.

quiz_1_question.eng:
What warning signs do you see here?

The ex-boyfriend:

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Yes, these are important warning signs!

Sharing sexual images without permission is wrong and often a crime—especially if someone is under 18.

@data.characters.friend_female_2.name may feel ashamed and confused. She needs to know it’s not her fault and talk to someone she trusts.

Talk as a family about social media to help everyone stay safe.

text_2.eng: Teacher asks @data.characters.f1_daughter_16.name to stay after school

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.f1_daughter_16.name, if you want to get good grades this year you need to stay after school when everyone is gone so I can tutor you.

character_2_text.eng: My friend also needs support. Can I invite her too?

character_3_text.eng: No, this will be our secret. You don't want people to think you are stupid, right?

quiz_1_question.eng:
What warning signs do you see here?

The teacher:

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Yes, all of these are warning signs! Schools have rules to keep students safe. The teacher is abusing his power and knows it’s wrong.

He may have done this before and could do it again. @data.characters.f1_daughter_16.name can try to find others with the same experience to help report him to a trusted adult.

The man:

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Yes, all of these are warning signs! Your ‘no’ should always be respected.

Also remember, if people at home or outside use alcohol and other drugs this can be a warning sign, as those can make people angry, aggressive, and even violent.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
We’ve looked at warning signs. Now let’s think—what can we do if we don’t feel safe?

If you feel unsafe, you can say or do anything to stay safe. The goal is to get away!

Think about the moment when @data.characters.f2_daughter_19.name was pressured into a car.

How could she use her voice to get away?

text_2.eng:
**Find a chair and pretend it is the attacker. Practise saying/doing these responses:**

- 🔈 Yell: "No!" 
- 🆘 Call for help: "Someone help me!" 
- ⚠️ Warn of consequences: "I will call the police if you touch me again."
- ⛔ Name the behaviour: "Do not touch my bum.” or “Do not yell at me.”
- 😳 Act crazy: "Make a crazy scream or act like a gorilla!"
- 🚶🏾‍♀️ Pretend to go along to buy time: “I will do anything you want, just please don’t hurt me.”
- 🤡 Use humour: “No lift for me, thanks. Last time I got a lift I threw up EVERYWHERE!”
- 📱 Give something to get what you want: “I will give you my phone if you let me go.”

rows.text_2:
**Find a chair and pretend it is the attacker. Practise saying/doing these responses:**

- 🔈 Yell: "No!" 
- 🆘 Call for help: "Someone help me!" 
- ⚠️ Warn of consequences: "I will call the police if you touch me again."
- ⛔ Name the behaviour: "Do not touch my bum.” or “Do not yell at me.”
- 😳 Act crazy: "Make a crazy scream or act like a gorilla!"
- 🚶🏾‍♀️ Pretend to go along to buy time: “I will do anything you want, just please don’t hurt me.”
- 🤡 Use humour: “No lift for me, thanks. Last time I got a lift I threw up EVERYWHERE!”
- 📱 Give something to get what you want: “I will give you my phone if you let me go.”

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s think back to @data.characters.f2_daughter_19.name’s dangerous situation.

quiz_1_question.eng: Could this situation happen to a boy?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: It’s true. Both boys and girls can find themselves in dangerous situations.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That’s not quite right. Both boys and girls can find themselves in dangerous situations.

quiz_2_question.eng: Could a boy use his voice to get away?

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng: Boys and girls can both find themselves in dangerous situations. Both boys and girls are allowed to do, say, and believe anything that will help them stay safe.

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: Boys and girls can both find themselves in dangerous situations. Both boys and girls are allowed to do, say, and believe anything that will help them stay safe.

text_1_facilitator.eng: When our voice does not stop the situation, we can use our bodies to defend ourselves.

section_1_title.eng: Learn how to protect yourself by knowing weak spots on an attacker’s body:

section_1_text.eng:
**EYES**
- Use your fingers as claws and scratch the attacker’s face as hard as possible.

- Push your thumbs into the eye sockets of your attacker and then outward towards the sides of their head.

**THROAT**
- Push your finger into the hole at the bottom of the attacker’s throat.

- Punch the throat with your fist or the back of your elbow.

**GROIN**
- Kick the attacker’s groin with your knee, or punch it with your fist or elbow.

- Grab, squeeze, twist and pull the attacker’s testicles with your hand.

**KNEES**
- Kick against your attacker's knee with your foot.

rows.section_1_title: Learn how to protect yourself by knowing weak spots on an attacker’s body:
rows.section_1_text:
**EYES**
- Use your fingers as claws and scratch the attacker’s face as hard as possible.

- Push your thumbs into the eye sockets of your attacker and then outward towards the sides of their head.

**THROAT**
- Push your finger into the hole at the bottom of the attacker’s throat.

- Punch the throat with your fist or the back of your elbow.

**GROIN**
- Kick the attacker’s groin with your knee, or punch it with your fist or elbow.

- Grab, squeeze, twist and pull the attacker’s testicles with your hand.

**KNEES**
- Kick against your attacker's knee with your foot.
rows.text_1_facilitator: When our voice does not stop the situation, we can use our bodies to defend ourselves.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Take a look at the image and these examples to see how you can use the weak spots or targets on your attacker’s body.

section_1_title.eng: Learn how to protect yourself by knowing weak spots on an attacker’s body:

section_1_text.eng:
**TEMPLES**
- Punch the attacker’s temples with your fist or the back of your elbow.
**NOSE** 
- Punch the attacker’s nose with your fist or the back of your elbow.
**EARS**
- With flat hands, smack the attacker’s ears from both sides as hard as possible. You can also pull or twist them.
**RIBS**
- Punch the attacker in the ribs with your fist or the back of your elbow.
**FINGERS**
- Pull the attacker's pinky or little finger away from the other fingers hard and fast (it breaks easily).
**SHINS**
- Kick against the attacker’s shins as hard as you can.
**TOP OF FEET**
- Lift your foot and stomp your heel on the top of your attacker’s foot.

rows.section_1_title: Learn how to protect yourself by knowing weak spots on an attacker’s body:
rows.section_1_text:
**TEMPLES**
- Punch the attacker’s temples with your fist or the back of your elbow.
**NOSE** 
- Punch the attacker’s nose with your fist or the back of your elbow.
**EARS**
- With flat hands, smack the attacker’s ears from both sides as hard as possible. You can also pull or twist them.
**RIBS**
- Punch the attacker in the ribs with your fist or the back of your elbow.
**FINGERS**
- Pull the attacker's pinky or little finger away from the other fingers hard and fast (it breaks easily).
**SHINS**
- Kick against the attacker’s shins as hard as you can.
**TOP OF FEET**
- Lift your foot and stomp your heel on the top of your attacker’s foot.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Here is an additional image to show you more examples of how you can use the weak spots or targets on your attacker’s body.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are some skills to help you and your teen stay safe!

section_1_text.eng:
Know the difference between healthy and unhealthy relationships. If someone hurts you, it is never your fault.

You are allowed to say and do what is needed to stay safe and get away—don’t worry about what others think.

You are worth defending. You are strong and powerful.

section_2_text.eng:
If someone says or does something that makes you feel uncomfortable, it’s not okay. We all have the right to feel safe, especially at home.

See the warning signs and trust your feelings. If you feel unsafe, the goal is to get away.

section_3_text.eng:
Your voice can help stop an attack. Yell, call for help, warn, act, or use humour to stay safe.

Be clear, confident, and direct—use your words, body, and eyes.

section_4_text.eng:
If your voice doesn’t help, use your body.

Know the strong parts of your body you can use, and where on the attacker’s body you can hit to stop them. Use what you can to protect yourself and get away.

section_4_extra_text.eng:
In danger, it’s normal to freeze or feel unsure. These tools can help you and your teen stay safe.

If you or your teen are hurt, it is never your fault. Talk to someone you trust.

As a parent, let your teen know they can always tell you anything, and you’ll find a solution together.

rows.section_1_text:
Know the difference between healthy and unhealthy relationships. If someone hurts you, it is never your fault.

You are allowed to say and do what is needed to stay safe and get away—don’t worry about what others think.

You are worth defending. You are strong and powerful.

rows.section_2_text:
If someone says or does something that makes you feel uncomfortable, it’s not okay. We all have the right to feel safe, especially at home.

See the warning signs and trust your feelings. If you feel unsafe, the goal is to get away.
rows.section_3_text:
Your voice can help stop an attack. Yell, call for help, warn, act, or use humour to stay safe.

Be clear, confident, and direct—use your words, body, and eyes.
rows.section_4_text:
If your voice doesn’t help, use your body.

Know the strong parts of your body you can use, and where on the attacker’s body you can hit to stop them. Use what you can to protect yourself and get away.
rows.section_4_extra_text:
In danger, it’s normal to freeze or feel unsure. These tools can help you and your teen stay safe.

If you or your teen are hurt, it is never your fault. Talk to someone you trust.

As a parent, let your teen know they can always tell you anything, and you’ll find a solution together.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
This week’s home activity is to talk with your teen about this Staying Safe module.

Try the activities on warning signs and using voice and body together.

These conversations can be hard at first, but they give your teen important skills for staying safe. You can do it!

text_2.eng:
**Remember to:**

⚠️ Spot warning signs: Talk with your teen about places, people, or situations that may not be safe. Remind them to trust their feelings.
📣 Use your voice: Practise saying “no” or asking for help.
🙅🏽‍♀️ Use your body: Make a plan together for how to leave or protect yourself.

quiz_1_question.eng: Can you discuss the Staying Safe module with your teen this week?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Fantastic! Going through this module’s skills makes it more likely your teen will act quickly and protect themselves when it matters most.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That is a good start! Every time you talk about safety, you make it easier for your teen to trust their instincts and speak up. Keep going!

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: That's okay. Safety talks can feel hard, but even one conversation can prepare your teen for real situations. You can try again when you are ready.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Fantastic! Going through this module’s skills makes it more likely your teen will act quickly and protect themselves when it matters most.

rows.quiz_1_question: Can you discuss the Staying Safe module with your teen this week?
rows.text_1_facilitator:
This week’s home activity is to talk with your teen about this Staying Safe module.

Try the activities on warning signs and using voice and body together.

These conversations can be hard at first, but they give your teen important skills for staying safe. You can do it!
rows.text_2:
**Remember to:**

⚠️ Spot warning signs: Talk with your teen about places, people, or situations that may not be safe. Remind them to trust their feelings.
📣 Use your voice: Practise saying “no” or asking for help.
🙅🏽‍♀️ Use your body: Make a plan together for how to leave or protect yourself.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Helping your teen learn to notice danger, speak up, and protect themselves builds real confidence.

Practising together makes it more likely they will act when something feels wrong.

media_title.eng: Hear how @data.characters.media_daughter_9.name used her voice to stay safe

media_transcript.eng: It helped me a lot that I learnt I can use my voice to stay safe. A while ago, I was walking home alone and some man began to follow me and I felt scared. My father taught me that the most important thing is to be safe, so I turned around and said loud and clear ‘Why are you following me, I don’t want that’. It really surprised the man and even some other people looked at us, so the man walked away. I felt so relieved and even told my father. He said I did well and I felt really good. Before, I would have been too scared, also what other people think, but now I feel confident.

Practising together makes it more likely they will act when something feels wrong.

My father taught me that the most important thing is to be safe, so I turned around and said loud and clear ‘Why are you following me, I don’t want that’. It really surprised the man and even some other people looked at us, so the man walked away. I felt so relieved and even told my father. He said I did well and I felt really good. Before, I would have been too scared, also what other people think, but now I feel confident.
